subject: Re: [junit] Promlem in writing Test case
msgSnippet: ... If you don t know what the expected result is, then by definition you cannot test for it. With this in mind, how do you know which version the XML file
messageBody:
On 11/14/06, avinash anand <avinash_anand@...> wrote:
> Hi Shane
> This here is something different. I want to testh this code in a
> dynamic enviroment, meaning the system will be feed with different
> xml files using diffrent permutation and combination. For instance if
> the current version installed is 7.1.1 and the xml file feed has a version
> 7.0.1 the code will return 0, if the current version is 6.1.5 and the xml
> file reads 7.1.0 the code will return 7.1.0 Hence I will never be sure
> of the expected result.

If you don't know what the expected result is, then by definition you
cannot test for it.

With this in mind, how do you know which version the XML file feed is?
Is the version number embedded in a known attribute/element? Perhaps
your test could pull out the version number using Alternative
Algorithm, e.g. using an XPath statement?

Lasse
